values.description:
Coulomb joint friction was added for BulletHingeJoint in pull request #1317, but it wasn't working for BulletSliderJoint (#1348). I just found an [upstream bug in bullet](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/328) that I've reported and for which I've submitted a fix that should make it into bullet 2.83. In the meantime, I have a workaround here for bullet 2.82.

I enabled the joint friction test for this joint in 25e5874 and will update with jenkins results when they are available.

To test manually, load the `joint_friction_demo.world` with ODE to see the expected behavior. There are 3 rows of pendulums and a row of prismatic joints at the back that have different friction values. Three links with prismatic joints should fall at different rates and one should remain still.
~~~
gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e ode
~~~
Then load with bullet to see that the prismatic joints are working now. Note that two rows of pendulums don't work, since they are using BulletUniversalJoints, which don't yet support joint friction.
~~~
gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e bullet
~~~

I also reduced some of the console spam from the BulletSliderJoint.
values.title: Coulomb friction for BulletSliderJoint (#1348)

summary.raw:
Coulomb joint friction was added for BulletHingeJoint in pull request #1317, but it wasn't working for BulletSliderJoint (#1348). I just found an [upstream bug in bullet](https://github.com/bulletphysics/bullet3/pull/328) that I've reported and for which I've submitted a fix that should make it into bullet 2.83. In the meantime, I have a workaround here for bullet 2.82.

I enabled the joint friction test for this joint in 25e5874 and will update with jenkins results when they are available.

To test manually, load the `joint_friction_demo.world` with ODE to see the expected behavior. There are 3 rows of pendulums and a row of prismatic joints at the back that have different friction values. Three links with prismatic joints should fall at different rates and one should remain still.
~~~
gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e ode
~~~
Then load with bullet to see that the prismatic joints are working now. Note that two rows of pendulums don't work, since they are using BulletUniversalJoints, which don't yet support joint friction.
~~~
gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e bullet
~~~

I also reduced some of the console spam from the BulletSliderJoint.
summary.html:
Coulomb joint friction was added for BulletHingeJoint in pull request #1317, but it wasn't working for BulletSliderJoint (#1348). I just found an upstream bug in bullet that I've reported and for which I've submitted a fix that should make it into bullet 2.83. In the meantime, I have a workaround here for bullet 2.82.

I enabled the joint friction test for this joint in 25e5874 and will update with jenkins results when they are available.

To test manually, load the joint_friction_demo.world with ODE to see the expected behavior. There are 3 rows of pendulums and a row of prismatic joints at the back that have different friction values. Three links with prismatic joints should fall at different rates and one should remain still.

gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e ode

Then load with bullet to see that the prismatic joints are working now. Note that two rows of pendulums don't work, since they are using BulletUniversalJoints, which don't yet support joint friction.

gazebo --verbose worlds/joint_friction_demo.world -e bullet

I also reduced some of the console spam from the BulletSliderJoint.

values.title: ServerFixture: replace "using namespace gazebo;" with "namespace gazebo {}"

summary.html:
It's bad practice to use using namespace gazebo; in header files. This pull request replaces this with namespace gazebo and brackets in 580691b. The following commit (6e10861) is purely indentation and fixing long line lengths. The last commit (c4f8e74) fixes some build errors related to the change in namespacing.

A more concise diff that ignores most of the whitespace using the -b flag:

$ hg up serverfixture_namespace2
$ hg diff -r gazebo5 -b test/ServerFixture.hh
diff -r afb30274a742 test/ServerFixture.hh
--- a/test/ServerFixture.hh Fri Feb 20 18:10:50 2015 -0800
+++ b/test/ServerFixture.hh Mon Feb 23 14:09:27 2015 -0800
@@ -52,12 +52,12 @@

 #include "test_config.h"

-using namespace gazebo;
+namespace gazebo
+{
+  std::string custom_exec(std::string _cmd);

-std::string custom_exec(std::string _cmd);
-
-class ServerFixture : public testing::Test
-{
+  class ServerFixture : public testing::Test
+  {
   /// \brief Constructor
   protected: ServerFixture();

@@ -75,7 +75,8 @@
   /// paused/un-paused.
   /// \param[in] _worldFilename Name of the world to load.
   /// \param[in] _paused True to start the world paused.
-  protected: virtual void Load(const std::string &_worldFilename, bool _paused);
+    protected: virtual void Load(const std::string &_worldFilename,
+                                 bool _paused);

   /// \brief Load a world based on a filename and set simulation
   /// paused/un-paused, and specify physics engine.
@@ -135,7 +136,8 @@
   /// \param[in] _height Height of the image.
   /// \param[in] _depth Pixel depth.
   protected: void PrintImage(const std::string &_name, unsigned char **_image,
-                unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height, unsigned int _depth);
+                  unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height,
+                  unsigned int _depth);

   /// \brief Print laser scan to screen. This is used to generate test data.
   /// \param[in] _name Name to associate with the printed data.
@@ -179,7 +181,8 @@
   /// \param[out] _diffAvg Average difference between the two arrays.
   protected: void ImageCompare(unsigned char *_imageA,
                  unsigned char *_imageB,
-                 unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height, unsigned int _depth,
+                   unsigned int _width, unsigned int _height,
+                   unsigned int _depth,
                  unsigned int &_diffMax, unsigned int &_diffSum,
                  double &_diffAvg);

@@ -336,7 +339,8 @@
   /// log message about the problem.
   /// \param[in] log_msg: error msg related to the timeout
   /// \param[in] timeoutCS: failing period (in centiseconds)
-  private: void launchTimeoutFailure(const char *_logMsg, const int _timeoutCS);
+    private: void launchTimeoutFailure(const char *_logMsg,
+                                       const int _timeoutCS);

   /// \brief Spawn an Wireless transmitter sensor on a link
   /// \param[in] _name Model name
@@ -412,7 +416,8 @@
   /// \param[in] _spotOuterAngle Outer angle ("spot" only).
   /// \param[in] _spotFallOff Fall off ("spot" only).
   /// \param[in] _castShadows True to cast shadows.
-  protected: void SpawnLight(const std::string &_name, const std::string &_type,
+    protected: void SpawnLight(const std::string &_name,
+                   const std::string &_type,
                  const math::Vector3 &_pos, const math::Vector3 &_rpy,
                  const common::Color &_diffuse = common::Color::White,
                  const common::Color &_specular = common::Color::White,
@@ -567,5 +572,6 @@

   /// \brief True if server is running.
   private: bool serverRunning;
-};
+  };
+}       // namespace gazebo
 #endif  // define _GAZEBO_SERVER_FIXTURE_HH_

values.title: Implemented AddLinkForce for ODE with integration tests

summary.html:
Some sort of Add*Force function is needed to be used with the Apply Force GUI.

The current Link::Add*Force API is not very clear. Talking to @scpeters, we thought of adding 3 new functions as follows, and eventually deprecating the currently existing ones.

      /// \brief Add a force expressed in the world frame.
      /// \param[in] _force Direction vector expressed in the world frame. 
      /// Each component corresponds to the force which will be added in that axis.
      /// \param[in] _offset Offset position expressed in the world frame. 
      /// It defaults to the world origin.
      public: virtual void AddWorldForce(const math::Vector3 &_force,
          const math::Vector3 &_offset = math::Vector3::Zero) = 0;

      /// \brief Add a force expressed in the link frame.
      /// \param[in] _force Direction vector expressed in the link frame. 
      /// Each component corresponds to the force which will be added in that axis.
      /// \param[in] _offset Offset position expressed in the link frame. 
      /// It defaults to the link origin.
      public: virtual void AddLinkForce(const math::Vector3 &_force,
          const math::Vector3 &_offset = math::Vector3::Zero) = 0;

      /// \brief Add a force expressed in the CoG (inertia) frame.
      /// \param[in] _force Direction vector expressed in the CoG frame. 
      /// Each component corresponds to the force which will be added in that axis.
      /// \param[in] _offset Offset position expressed in the CoG frame. It defaults 
      /// to the = CoG.
      public: virtual void AddCoGForce(const math::Vector3 &_force,
          const math::Vector3 &_offset = math::Vector3::Zero) = 0;

This PR implements one of them, AddLinkForce, which is the one needed for the Apply Force GUI. You can try out the GUI on branch apply_force_dialog if you want to see the function in action.

This PR includes integration tests for the new function. Four Five Six situations are tested, each with a combination of frame poses and application points which hopefully cover most of the possibilities without too much overlap. But it's very much likely that these are very bad test cases...

Below you can see how I expect the cases to be working. xyz are the axes of the world frame (W), link frame (L) and inertial frame (I).

The first 4 All test cases are passing. But I did some weird stuff to make some tests pass. Still working on fixing test 5. More specifically, in lines 377 and 383/384. Having that said, I'm sure there's a lot more weird stuff I'm not aware of.

`quickstep_util` contains the math utility functions 

`quickstep_cg_lcp` and `quickstep_sor_lcp` are the LCP Solvers 

`quickstep_update_bodies` will update the bodies in the world with the returned forces from solvers

values.description:
This pull request adds a new function to ServerFixture: `physics::ModelPtr SpawnModel(msgs::Model)` that spawns a model from a `msgs::Model` and returns a `physics::ModelPtr`. This can simplify test code that calls a `void` spawn function, waits, and then gets the `ModelPtr` from the world.

To demonstrate it, I simplify the `SpawnJoint` function in `joint_test.hh` and also the `LinkGetWorldInertia` test. This test was in `physics_friction.cc` so that it could use a custom spawning function from that test, but using `SpawnModel(msgs::Model)` allows me to move the test to `physics_link.cc`, which is a better place for it.
values.title: Add ServerFixture::SpawnModel(msgs::Model) and use some ToSDF functions in tests

summary.raw:
This pull request adds a new function to ServerFixture: `physics::ModelPtr SpawnModel(msgs::Model)` that spawns a model from a `msgs::Model` and returns a `physics::ModelPtr`. This can simplify test code that calls a `void` spawn function, waits, and then gets the `ModelPtr` from the world.

To demonstrate it, I simplify the `SpawnJoint` function in `joint_test.hh` and also the `LinkGetWorldInertia` test. This test was in `physics_friction.cc` so that it could use a custom spawning function from that test, but using `SpawnModel(msgs::Model)` allows me to move the test to `physics_link.cc`, which is a better place for it.
summary.html:
This pull request adds a new function to ServerFixture: physics::ModelPtr SpawnModel(msgs::Model) that spawns a model from a msgs::Model and returns a physics::ModelPtr. This can simplify test code that calls a void spawn function, waits, and then gets the ModelPtr from the world.

To demonstrate it, I simplify the SpawnJoint function in joint_test.hh and also the LinkGetWorldInertia test. This test was in physics_friction.cc so that it could use a custom spawning function from that test, but using SpawnModel(msgs::Model) allows me to move the test to physics_link.cc, which is a better place for it.

values.description:
Implementation of the Physics Preset Profile API [design](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/e64787224f59902a986c22f7d20fdb39e24b8764/physics_presets/physics_presets.md).

~~Requires sdformat [PR146](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/146/physics-preset-attributes/diff)~~ merged

This PR adds an API for switching between different physics profiles, specified as physics blocks in SDF.

I also included 2 small fixes the ODEPhysics and SimbodyPhysics to handle exceptions.

A forthcoming PR will implement the command line interface to `PresetManager` ([preview](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/physics_presets_cli)) and the ability to generate SDF from physics profiles.

Known issue(s):

In physics elements with elements of different types, e.g. `test/worlds/presets.world` has `preset1` which has `ode`, `simbody` and `bullet` blocks, `PresetManager` will attempt to set all parameters specified in the profile. An optimization would be to only set parameters for the engine that is specified in the `type` attribute of `physics`. Since this is not currently implemented, the test gives a lot of warnings, such as `[Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:225] SetParam failed for [cfm] in physics engine simbody`.

~~The implementation of `PresetManager` relies on `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. `SetParam` is not implemented for Simbody, so the functionality of this PR will not work with Simbody. (If/when [PR1473](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1473/) gets merged before this, I will complete the `PresetManager` test to include Simbody.~~ merged and simbody test integrated

~~For all the physics engines, `SetParam` is not fully implemented for certain parameters, so you may receive lots of gzwarnings from the `PhysicsEngine` implementation in gzserver.~~ Fixed by [PR1528](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1528/call-physicsengine-setparam-in-child/diff)

A unit test for `PresetManager` should be added to get to ~90% coverage.
values.title: `PresetManager` for physics library

summary.raw:
Implementation of the Physics Preset Profile API [design](#!/osrf/gazebo_design/src/e64787224f59902a986c22f7d20fdb39e24b8764/physics_presets/physics_presets.md).

~~Requires sdformat [PR146](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/146/physics-preset-attributes/diff)~~ merged

This PR adds an API for switching between different physics profiles, specified as physics blocks in SDF.

I also included 2 small fixes the ODEPhysics and SimbodyPhysics to handle exceptions.

A forthcoming PR will implement the command line interface to `PresetManager` ([preview](#!/osrf/gazebo/branch/physics_presets_cli)) and the ability to generate SDF from physics profiles.

Known issue(s):

In physics elements with elements of different types, e.g. `test/worlds/presets.world` has `preset1` which has `ode`, `simbody` and `bullet` blocks, `PresetManager` will attempt to set all parameters specified in the profile. An optimization would be to only set parameters for the engine that is specified in the `type` attribute of `physics`. Since this is not currently implemented, the test gives a lot of warnings, such as `[Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:225] SetParam failed for [cfm] in physics engine simbody`.

~~The implementation of `PresetManager` relies on `PhysicsEngine::SetParam`. `SetParam` is not implemented for Simbody, so the functionality of this PR will not work with Simbody. (If/when [PR1473](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1473/) gets merged before this, I will complete the `PresetManager` test to include Simbody.~~ merged and simbody test integrated

~~For all the physics engines, `SetParam` is not fully implemented for certain parameters, so you may receive lots of gzwarnings from the `PhysicsEngine` implementation in gzserver.~~ Fixed by [PR1528](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/1528/call-physicsengine-setparam-in-child/diff)

A unit test for `PresetManager` should be added to get to ~90% coverage.
summary.html:
Implementation of the Physics Preset Profile API design.

Requires sdformat PR146 merged

This PR adds an API for switching between different physics profiles, specified as physics blocks in SDF.

I also included 2 small fixes the ODEPhysics and SimbodyPhysics to handle exceptions.

A forthcoming PR will implement the command line interface to PresetManager (preview) and the ability to generate SDF from physics profiles.

Known issue(s):

In physics elements with elements of different types, e.g. test/worlds/presets.world has preset1 which has ode, simbody and bullet blocks, PresetManager will attempt to set all parameters specified in the profile. An optimization would be to only set parameters for the engine that is specified in the type attribute of physics. Since this is not currently implemented, the test gives a lot of warnings, such as [Wrn] [PhysicsEngine.cc:225] SetParam failed for [cfm] in physics engine simbody.

The implementation of PresetManager relies on PhysicsEngine::SetParam. SetParam is not implemented for Simbody, so the functionality of this PR will not work with Simbody. (If/when PR1473 gets merged before this, I will complete the PresetManager test to include Simbody. merged and simbody test integrated

For all the physics engines, SetParam is not fully implemented for certain parameters, so you may receive lots of gzwarnings from the PhysicsEngine implementation in gzserver. Fixed by PR1528

A unit test for PresetManager should be added to get to ~90% coverage.

values.description:
This function makes handle material changing public.

Needed for the Apply Force/Torque GUI.

Also changed the logic of setting visibility for groups of handles because the children's visibility wasn't well handled before (newly introduced tests would fail). This was first introduced on pull request #1417.

values.description:
Implement `SimbodyPhysics::SetParam` based on the specification in SDF. Part of [issue1116](#!/osrf/gazebo/issue/1116/update-simbody-physics-parameters-add), though not a complete fix (still need to fully implement `SimbodyPhysics::GetParam`).

I also removed a lot of code from the physics engine implementations by making a static templated helper function in PhysicsEngine to catch exceptions from boost::any_cast.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/561/)
values.title: Implemented SimbodyPhysics::SetParam and slimmed down physics engines

I also removed a lot of code from the physics engine implementations by making a static templated helper function in PhysicsEngine to catch exceptions from boost::any_cast.

[Jenkins](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-any-devel-trusty-amd64-gpu-nvidia/561/)

values.description:
A few of the variables were matched up incorrectly; just look at the names.

I got a hint of this bug from [this compiler warning](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-homebrew-amd64/488/warnings6Result/source.273774/#247).

This lacks a test, but that will be addressed later. This fix should be straightforward to review.

summary.html:
A few of the variables were matched up incorrectly; just look at the names.

I got a hint of this bug from this compiler warning.

This lacks a test, but that will be addressed later. This fix should be straightforward to review.

values.description:
Issue #1473

Instead of checking the model name, check the geometry of its grandchildren (visuals/collisions).

Scaling still works only for centred simple shapes consisting of a single geometry type.

You can try to scale the `Beer` model for example and it won't work because it is not centred. Then go into the model editor, centre the link and save it as a new model, and then scaling should work.
values.title: Allow scaling of simple shapes regardless of model name

values.description: There were some functions in `PhysicsEngine` that seemed specific to ODE and/or Bullet (`Get/SetWorldCFM`, `Get/SetContactSurfaceArea`, etc.). I deprecated them and patched some of the tests that call these functions from `PhysicsEngine`.
values.title: Deprecated ODE-specific functions in PhysicsEngine

values.description:
This pull request implements the `self_collide` boolean for Model.

If model `self_collide` is true, all links will be considered to collide with each other unless `self_collide` is specified as false in the link.

See new test case added to `integration/physics_collision.cc` and world `model_self_collide.world` for an example.

[Companion SDF pull request](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/149/added-self_collide-element-for-model/diff)
values.title: Implemented self_collide bool for Model

values.description:
While working on pull request #1456, I found the need for a function to return the angular momentum of a Link (inertia matrix times the angular velocity). I've added a test here based on conservation of angular momentum with gyroscopic tumbling of a box with relative dimensions 1x4x9, which looks [something like this](https://vimeo.com/105581956). With no external torques acting, the angular momentum of the box should be constant in the world frame.

In 1879a77e48a0, the tolerance is such that only ODE and simbody pass the test. In 8263602eb9df, I set a flag to enable consideration of gyroscopic forces in bullet, which allows bullet to pass. In ee2df6af178a, I relax the tolerance for dart to allow it to pass. This is something I've discussed with the dart developers, though I don't think there's an issue in any issue tracker yet.

I also fixed a [warning on OS X in physics_collision.cc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/20/warnings6Result/package.-566429772/).
values.title: Add Link::GetWorldAngularMomentum, enable bullet gyroscopic forces

summary.raw:
While working on pull request #1456, I found the need for a function to return the angular momentum of a Link (inertia matrix times the angular velocity). I've added a test here based on conservation of angular momentum with gyroscopic tumbling of a box with relative dimensions 1x4x9, which looks [something like this](https://vimeo.com/105581956). With no external torques acting, the angular momentum of the box should be constant in the world frame.

In 1879a77e48a0, the tolerance is such that only ODE and simbody pass the test. In 8263602eb9df, I set a flag to enable consideration of gyroscopic forces in bullet, which allows bullet to pass. In ee2df6af178a, I relax the tolerance for dart to allow it to pass. This is something I've discussed with the dart developers, though I don't think there's an issue in any issue tracker yet.

I also fixed a [warning on OS X in physics_collision.cc](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-default-devel-homebrew-amd64-2/20/warnings6Result/package.-566429772/).
summary.html:
While working on pull request #1456, I found the need for a function to return the angular momentum of a Link (inertia matrix times the angular velocity). I've added a test here based on conservation of angular momentum with gyroscopic tumbling of a box with relative dimensions 1x4x9, which looks something like this. With no external torques acting, the angular momentum of the box should be constant in the world frame.

In 1879a77e48a0, the tolerance is such that only ODE and simbody pass the test. In 8263602eb9df, I set a flag to enable consideration of gyroscopic forces in bullet, which allows bullet to pass. In ee2df6af178a, I relax the tolerance for dart to allow it to pass. This is something I've discussed with the dart developers, though I don't think there's an issue in any issue tracker yet.

I also fixed a warning on OS X in physics_collision.cc.

values.description:
Click on `Add` on the palette and choose an SVG file to extrude.

![extruded2.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/3987015382-extruded2.png)

![extruded1.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/592780571-extruded1.png)

* `SVGLoader` fix courtesy of @hugomatic

* `Visual` fix courtesy of @iche033

* Known issues:

    * Models made with the editor don't collide with ground plane and will fall through (#1492)

    * Polyline materials missing normals and texture coordinates (#1485)

    * Not possible to extrude SVG paths which:

        * Have too many points/samples

        * Have crossed lines

values.description:
Several things:

1. We just made a prerelease of `libsdformat3` for use with the default branch of gazebo. Since we are using `find_package(SDFormat 2)` and sdformat's cmake config file is using `SameMajorVersion`, it won't accept sdformat3. So I add `find_package(SDFormat 3)` if the first one fails.

2. sdformat behavior was changed in 2.3.1 to [ignore unknown elements](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/148/ignore-unknown-elements/diff). This causes a `UNIT_msgs_TEST` failure, which I fix here. I also bumped the minimum sdformat2 version to 2.3.1 to ensure that the test will pass.

3. Make `INTEGRATION_factory` a DRI test, since it uses a pr2 with a camera. It has been [failing in the non-GPU jenkins jobs](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64/1250/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_factory/test_ran/).

4. Fix SDF shasums in `UNIT_gz_TEST`. It's annoying to fix these all the time (#1332), and it occurred to me that we could move the `gz sdf` tool functionality to a separate command-line tool in the sdformat repository ([sdformat issue 85](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/85/gz-sdf-command-line-tool-should-be-in)), which would make it easier to keep the test in sync with the sdformat description.

I'll update with Jenkins results as available.
values.title: gazebo5: allow sdformat3 and fix tests

summary.raw:
Several things:

1. We just made a prerelease of `libsdformat3` for use with the default branch of gazebo. Since we are using `find_package(SDFormat 2)` and sdformat's cmake config file is using `SameMajorVersion`, it won't accept sdformat3. So I add `find_package(SDFormat 3)` if the first one fails.

2. sdformat behavior was changed in 2.3.1 to [ignore unknown elements](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-request/148/ignore-unknown-elements/diff). This causes a `UNIT_msgs_TEST` failure, which I fix here. I also bumped the minimum sdformat2 version to 2.3.1 to ensure that the test will pass.

3. Make `INTEGRATION_factory` a DRI test, since it uses a pr2 with a camera. It has been [failing in the non-GPU jenkins jobs](http://build.osrfoundation.org/view/gazebo/job/gazebo-default-devel-trusty-amd64/1250/testReport/junit/(root)/INTEGRATION_factory/test_ran/).

4. Fix SDF shasums in `UNIT_gz_TEST`. It's annoying to fix these all the time (#1332), and it occurred to me that we could move the `gz sdf` tool functionality to a separate command-line tool in the sdformat repository ([sdformat issue 85](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/issue/85/gz-sdf-command-line-tool-should-be-in)), which would make it easier to keep the test in sync with the sdformat description.

I'll update with Jenkins results as available.
summary.html:
Several things:

  1. We just made a prerelease of libsdformat3 for use with the default branch of gazebo. Since we are using find_package(SDFormat 2) and sdformat's cmake config file is using SameMajorVersion, it won't accept sdformat3. So I add find_package(SDFormat 3) if the first one fails.

  2. sdformat behavior was changed in 2.3.1 to ignore unknown elements. This causes a UNIT_msgs_TEST failure, which I fix here. I also bumped the minimum sdformat2 version to 2.3.1 to ensure that the test will pass.

  3. Make INTEGRATION_factory a DRI test, since it uses a pr2 with a camera. It has been failing in the non-GPU jenkins jobs.

  4. Fix SDF shasums in UNIT_gz_TEST. It's annoying to fix these all the time (#1332), and it occurred to me that we could move the gz sdf tool functionality to a separate command-line tool in the sdformat repository (sdformat issue 85), which would make it easier to keep the test in sync with the sdformat description.

I'll update with Jenkins results as available.

values.description:
We had a bad connection between QT and OGRE. Basically too many timers.

The primary changes:

1. Remove QTimer from `gui/RenderWidget`
1. Properly set the time the last frame was rendered in `rendering/Camera.cc`

Prior to this change the UserCamera would render somewhere between 20 and 30Hz. It will now reach over 60, and over a few hundred Hz if you adjust the update rate in UserCamera (also depends on your graphics card, and the type of world).

You'll most likely notice that the GUI feels more snappy.

A soon-to-follow pull request to default will add a test. Have to put the test in default because it breaks ABI.

**Update**: Test added.

**Update**: This is the backport of pull request #1488
values.title: Fix QT rendering, and rendering update rate

Prior to this change the UserCamera would render somewhere between 20 and 30Hz. It will now reach over 60, and over a few hundred Hz if you adjust the update rate in UserCamera (also depends on your graphics card, and the type of world).

You'll most likely notice that the GUI feels more snappy.

summary.html:
We had a bad connection between QT and OGRE. Basically too many timers.

The primary changes:

  1. Remove QTimer from gui/RenderWidget
  2. Properly set the time the last frame was rendered in rendering/Camera.cc

Prior to this change the UserCamera would render somewhere between 20 and 30Hz. It will now reach over 60, and over a few hundred Hz if you adjust the update rate in UserCamera (also depends on your graphics card, and the type of world).

You'll most likely notice that the GUI feels more snappy.

A soon-to-follow pull request to default will add a test. Have to put the test in default because it breaks ABI.

Update: Test added.

Update: This is the backport of pull request #1488

values.description:
Issue #1457

This is not the only Ctrl-key related issue observed recently. So instead of using `mouseEvent.control`, I switched to `Qt::ControlModifier` which seems to be more reliable.

~~I also made rotations snap to absolute coordinates instead of taking the initial offset. This is something @spaepcke had asked me a while ago.~~ not doing this for now
values.title: Fix snapping inside editor

summary.raw:
Issue #1457

This is not the only Ctrl-key related issue observed recently. So instead of using `mouseEvent.control`, I switched to `Qt::ControlModifier` which seems to be more reliable.

~~I also made rotations snap to absolute coordinates instead of taking the initial offset. This is something @spaepcke had asked me a while ago.~~ not doing this for now
summary.html:
Issue #1457

This is not the only Ctrl-key related issue observed recently. So instead of using mouseEvent.control, I switched to Qt::ControlModifier which seems to be more reliable.

I also made rotations snap to absolute coordinates instead of taking the initial offset. This is something @spaepcke had asked me a while ago. not doing this for now

issue #1492

I originally proposed setting a default value in the protobuf message for this, but I decided instead to go with what appears to be the current convention of setting default values for a protobuf message in `CollisionConfig`.
values.title: Fixed issue 1492

summary.raw:
issue #1492

I originally proposed setting a default value in the protobuf message for this, but I decided instead to go with what appears to be the current convention of setting default values for a protobuf message in `CollisionConfig`.
summary.html:
issue #1492

I originally proposed setting a default value in the protobuf message for this, but I decided instead to go with what appears to be the current convention of setting default values for a protobuf message in CollisionConfig.

values.title: Speed up World::Step in loops

summary.html:
In many of my physics tests, I like to check things after every timestep. With the world paused, I use loops like the following:

for (lots of steps)
{
  world->Step(1);
  // get physics properties and check their validity
}

I added a test to INTEGRATION_speed that shows that this currently can't go faster than real-time. The problem was a 1 ms wait in the World::Step(unsigned int) function. I changed it to a 1 ns wait and now the test passes.

I need this for my accuracy testing branch.

values.description:
Removing redundant updates in

- UserCamera's mouse move event callback. In most cases, GLWidget's mouse move callback calls `GetVisual` which performs the update already.

- UserCamera's `GetVisual` - `OnSelectionClick` in the line that follows will perform the update.
values.title: Reduce selection buffer updates -> 4.1

summary.raw:
Removing redundant updates in

- UserCamera's mouse move event callback. In most cases, GLWidget's mouse move callback calls `GetVisual` which performs the update already.

- UserCamera's `GetVisual` - `OnSelectionClick` in the line that follows will perform the update.
summary.html:
Removing redundant updates in

  • UserCamera's mouse move event callback. In most cases, GLWidget's mouse move callback calls GetVisual which performs the update already.

  • UserCamera's GetVisual - OnSelectionClick in the line that follows will perform the update.

values.description:
I added a new param accessor to `PhysicsEngine` that returns a boolean and takes an output parameter as a reference. It returns false if the input key was not found and does not change the output value. This makes the API more robust and communicative about errors.

p.s. The branch name is a little misleading because my original intention was to create a templated function that automatically casts the boost::any value to a primitive type, but I will address this in a future PR.
values.title: Added boolean, pass by reference value GetParam to PhysicsEngine

summary.raw:
I added a new param accessor to `PhysicsEngine` that returns a boolean and takes an output parameter as a reference. It returns false if the input key was not found and does not change the output value. This makes the API more robust and communicative about errors.

p.s. The branch name is a little misleading because my original intention was to create a templated function that automatically casts the boost::any value to a primitive type, but I will address this in a future PR.
summary.html:
I added a new param accessor to PhysicsEngine that returns a boolean and takes an output parameter as a reference. It returns false if the input key was not found and does not change the output value. This makes the API more robust and communicative about errors.

p.s. The branch name is a little misleading because my original intention was to create a templated function that automatically casts the boost::any value to a primitive type, but I will address this in a future PR.

values.description:
This is a slight modification of the `tools/bitbucket_pullrequests` tool. Currently the `--check [id]` option will run code_check on the files modified by a pull request with the specified `id`, or if `id` is not specified, it will check all open pull requests.

This pull request adds an option to check the files modified by the parent commit. I'm currently using it in the https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo job. It can be invoked with `--check 0`, since the first pull request was pull request #1. If this is too much of a hack, I can create a separate command-line argument.
values.title: Add option to run code_check on files modified by parent commit

This pull request adds an option to check the files modified by the parent commit. I'm currently using it in the https://drone.io/bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo job. It can be invoked with `--check 0`, since the first pull request was pull request #1. If this is too much of a hack, I can create a separate command-line argument.
